the score-hungry Garnet eleven at

McClean will lead the eleven from

Van Orman and Pasarew will start
at the ends; Ellis and Orth, at the

stationed at the guards. Hallibert

The Jay aerial attack was halted
against Haverford by a slow field,
but McClean, the Jay sending station,
and Reynolds, Pasarew, Van Orman
and other receivers are more than
likely to swing back into action
against the Garnets.' Overhead attacks have been the Flock's most
effective weapon all year and will
undoubtedly be aimed at the host
gridders.
Coach Pfann of the Swarthmore
clan has engineered no changes in his
team's make-up. The Garnets will
open with McCormack and Heavenrich at the flanks, Turner and Heilig
at the tackles, Bright and Clement at
the guards, with Kenne disporting at
center. The backfield,,a light but
rather diversified unit, has Peter
calling from quarterback, Perkins
and Spruance at the halves, and
Buckingham at fullback.

From Badminton
To Worse
Shriveled up tennis. That's what
they called badminton. But it's
a faster, harder game than tennis.
Faster and harder even than the
brand of tennis displayed by Perry, Tilden, Vines—or McCleary.
Gains In Popularity
Last week Hopkins got its first
taste of badminton. It started out
with a few curious onlookers and
ended with over a score of badminton bugs. The reason? You can
let loose with every stroke. And
after a little while cut shots and
all other fawncy tennis -stuff may
be developed.
Equipment? The game is played
on a court about the size of a volleyball court. The court will be
furnished by the college. If you
prefer your own court, bring it
up to the gym and see who cares.
In some cases racquets will be
supplied, but birdies—that's the
name of the bunch of feathers you
try to slam over the net—will have
to come from the players.
Or
maybe some spectators will give
the players the bird.

Leagues Operating
All of the leagues now operating
on the campus are progressing rapidly and smoothly, with almost every
member of the University engaging
in some sort of athletic activity. All
men in fraternities are participating
in the inter-fraternity touch-football
league, and a lengthy schedule has
been arranged for the gridiron aspirants. Play started on Thursday, October 18, and will continue up until
December 13, on which date the last
game will be contested.
Progress in the inter-class lacrosse
league, which also supplies athletic
opportunities for many members of
the campus,is continuing. The seniors
and juniors meet on the upper field
today, while the freshmen and sophomores came to grips last Wednesday.
Unofficial Games
Aside from these offic0,1 leagues,
many independent sporting events
round out the undergraduate program. The Engineers and the dormitories engaged in a touch football
game on the lacrosse field last Wednesday. Informal soccer teams have
been organized, and provide an excellent form of varsity practice.
The graduate students have also
taken to the athletic fields for extra-curricular activity. Following the
example of the undergraduates, they
too have organized a league of their
own. The sport, however, is playground ball, and every afternoon the
dignitaries of six graduate departments may be seen cavorting on the
diamond formed beside Latrobe Hall.

With a minute and one half before the close of the game, the Kappa

team scored the deciding touchdown
to defeat the Tau Alpha Omega fraternity by a score of 8 to 6.

La Vie Collegienne.—'Muddleheaded" was the adjective used
by Dr. Bruce Raup of Columbia
University Teachers College in
describing the average college
professor of today.
The modern educator was also
indicted for not being able to
think clearly; he is unable to analyze problems thoroughly and
logically; he is a "yes" man; he
doesn't know anything about political, social or economic problems which don't bear directly on
the subject which he teaches, and
doesn't care to find out about
them.

When asked about the possibility
of a prompt revision of the Athletic
Association constitution, according to
suggestions made by Dr. Abercrombie, William McClean stated
Wednesday that he would consider
the matter as soon as time permitted.
He expects to appornt and call together members of the committee for
this revision at an early date.

The reason for this procedure is to
avoid all legitimate dissatisfaction
in the way Varsity Seals are awarded
as well as to make sure that their
award is to men who are deserving, in
the estimation of all the other members of the activity.
As a rule three years of steady
work in any one activity will be rewarded by a Seal with one star. An
additional star is to be given for the
same amount of work in each additional activity. Men who have attained a major office (president, editor, or business manager) will receive a Seal with two stars.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 2, 1934.

Scoring Famine
End Tomorrow
Hope To Tally For Initial
Time This Season At Expense Of Invading Jays

Back Shift Effective
Reynolds To Remain At Half
With Graziano Changing
To The Fullback Position
The Blue Jays invade the woods of
the score-hungry Garnet eleven at
Swarthmore tomorrow.
Swarthmore's Garnets have toiled
through an

unproductive

October,

their efforts to date yielding neither
a victory nor a score, but they're hoping the turn of the month will bring
Dickinson
about a turn in events.
topped the Garnets, 6 to 0; St. John's
belted them, 12 to 0; while Franklin
and Marshall jumped on them for a
22 to 0 win.
The Maroons, despite their lack of
punch on attack, have proven defensively stable and a much harder foe
than the scores suggest.
Pete

Reynold's

performance

at

right halfback against Haverford last
week-end convinced Ray Van Orman,
Jay mentor, of his increased value
at one of the halves. Pete will again
- iano, who
be at right half, with Graz
took over the fullback duties, continuing at the same post.
McClean will lead the eleven from
quarterback, with Kelly at left half.
Van Orman and Pasarew will start
at the ends; Ellis and Orth, at the
tackles; with Giardini and Phillips
stationed at the guards. Hallibert
will take over center.
The Jay aerial attack was halted
against Haverford by a slow field,
but McClean, the Jay sending station,
and Reynolds, Pasarew, Van Orman
and other receivers are more than
likely to swing back into action
against the Garnets.' Overhead attacks have been the Flock's most
effective weapon all year and will
undoubtedly be aimed at the host
gridders.

From Badminton
To Worse
Shriveled up tennis. That's what
they called badminton. But it's
a faster, harder game than tennis.
Faster and harder even than the
brand of tennis displayed by Perry, Tilden, Vines—or McCleary.
Gains In Popularity
Last week Hopkins got its first
taste of badminton. It started out
with a few curious onlookers and
ended with over a score of badminton bugs. The reason? You can
let loose with every stroke. And
after a little while cut shots and
all other fawncy tennis -stuff may
be developed.
Equipment? The game is played
on a court about the size of a volleyball court. The court will be
furnished by the college. If you
prefer your own court, bring it
up to the gym and see who cares.
In some cases racquets will be
supplied, but birdies—that's the
name of the bunch of feathers you
try to slam over the net—will have
to come from the players.
Or
maybe some spectators will give
the players the bird.

Leagues Operating
All of the leagues now operating
on the campus are progressing rapidly and smoothly, with almost every
member of the University engaging
in some sort of athletic activity. All
men in fraternities are participating
in the inter-fraternity touch-football
league, and a lengthy schedule has
been arranged for the gridiron aspirants. Play started on Thursday, October 18, and will continue up until
December 13, on which date the last
game will be contested.
Progress in the inter-class lacrosse
league, which also supplies athletic
opportunities for many members of
the campus,is continuing. The seniors
and juniors meet on the upper field
today, while the freshmen and sophomores came to grips last Wednesday.
Unofficial Games
Aside from these offic0,1 leagues,
many independent sporting events
round out the undergraduate program. The Engineers and the dormitories engaged in a touch football
game on the lacrosse field last Wednesday. Informal soccer teams have
been organized, and provide an excellent form of varsity practice.
The graduate students have also
taken to the athletic fields for extra-curricular activity. Following the
example of the undergraduates, they
too have organized a league of their
own. The sport, however, is playground ball, and every afternoon the
dignitaries of six graduate departments may be seen cavorting on the
diamond formed beside Latrobe Hall.

team scored the deciding touchdown

La Vie Collegienne.—'Muddleheaded" was the adjective used
by Dr. Bruce Raup of Columbia
University Teachers College in
describing the average college
professor of today.
The modern educator was also
indicted for not being able to
think clearly; he is unable to analyze problems thoroughly and
logically; he is a "yes" man; he
doesn't know anything about political, social or economic problems which don't bear directly on
the subject which he teaches, and
doesn't care to find out about
them.
